articles.headline: Fed Views Recession as Near an End
articles.snippet: The central bank gave its most upbeat assessment of the economy in more than a year.
articles.abstract: The central bank gave its most upbeat assessment of the economy in more than a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Almost exactly two years after it embarked on what was the biggest financial rescue in American history, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that the recession is ending and that it would take a step back toward normal policy.

articles.headline: Small-Business Stimulus Loans Off to Slow Start
articles.snippet: Banks are moving slowly to help companies hit by the recession, and the Small Business Administration is fine with that: the money will last longer.
articles.abstract: Banks are moving slowly to help companies hit by the recession, and the Small Business Administration is fine with that: the money will last longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Small-business owners hoping for some assistance of the sort given to the nation’s biggest banks applauded when the Small Business Administration unveiled a lending program in May.

articles.headline: A Leader Is Called On to Turn Around Lloyds
articles.snippet: In his new job in Britain, Winfried F.W. Bischoff has a chance to redeem himself after a frustrating experience in the United States.
articles.abstract: In his new job in Britain, Winfried F.W. Bischoff has a chance to redeem himself after a frustrating experience in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: On paper, Winfried F. W. Bischoff  whose most recent job was a brief stint at the helm of the heavily damaged Citigroup  has all the qualities one would expect in an incoming chairman of the equally troubled Lloyds Banking Group, one of Britain’s most storied banking names.

articles.headline: Jackson Earnings Grow by Millions After Death
articles.snippet: Since Michael Jackson’s death, merchandising contracts and a film deal have brought in about $100 million.
articles.abstract: Since Michael Jackson’s death, merchandising contracts and a film deal have brought in about $100 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been 48 days since Michael Jackson died, and while family members of the late pop star are still at war with the executors of his estate, the answer to another question  how much the singer is worth in death  is becoming clear. He has already earned $100 million through a film deal and various merchandising contracts, and the executors expect another $100 million to roll in by the end of the year.

articles.headline: A Window Into C.I.A.’s Embrace of Secret Jails
articles.snippet: One of the Bush administration’s most extraordinary counterterrorism programs had a fairly mundane start.
articles.abstract: One of the Bush administration’s most extraordinary counterterrorism programs had a fairly mundane start.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In March 2003, two C.I.A. officials surprised Kyle D. Foggo, then the chief of the agency’s main European supply base, with an unusual request. They wanted his help building secret prisons to hold some of the world’s most threatening terrorists.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Madoff Aide Holds Key to Intrigue
articles.snippet: Frank DiPascali, a longtime lieutenant who pleaded guilty this week, communicated directly with some large investors and feeder funds.
articles.abstract: Frank DiPascali, a longtime lieutenant who pleaded guilty this week, communicated directly with some large investors and feeder funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: What does Frank DiPascali know that makes him such a desirable witness for the federal prosecutors investigating the vast Ponzi scheme run by Bernard L. Madoff? And whom does he know it about?

articles.headline: Huge Bonus Hangs Over Pay Review
articles.snippet: Citibank may claim that an executive set to receive $100 million is exempt from federal review, executives said.
articles.abstract: Citibank may claim that an executive set to receive $100 million is exempt from federal review, executives said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Citigroup is planning to claim that an energy trader who is due to receive compensation of $100 million this year should be exempt from review by a federal authority given responsibility for setting pay packages at financial companies that received taxpayer bailouts, executives at the bank said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Independent Filmmakers Distribute on Their Own
articles.snippet: Instead of waiting to be discovered, aspiring filmmakers are paying for their own marketing and distribution.
articles.abstract: Instead of waiting to be discovered, aspiring filmmakers are paying for their own marketing and distribution.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Quentin Tarantino never had to go through this.
